awd_titl_txt: ATD:   Geospatial Graphical Models of Human Response to Emergencies
awd_abstract_narration:
Emergencies such as natural disasters and terrorist attacks occur frequently around the globe and regularly cause massive destruction. The goal of this project is to improve the ability to use publicly-available large-scale human-generated geospatial data sources for identification of emergency events. Currently, the largest impediment to using such data to identify emergency events is that very little is known about spatiotemporal patterns of human behavioral responses to these events. This project seeks to create novel machine learning tools to identify spatiotemporal patterns of reactions in human behavioral responses to emergency events using human-generated geospatial data sources.  The key research goals are: (1) build a corpus of geolocated emergency and non-emergency events; (2) develop state of the art machine learning models that detect geospatial clusters of locations with anomalous human behavior based on aggregated geolocated human activity data, together with advanced geographic information system visualizations; and (3) create a catalogue of behavioral signatures characterizing emergency and non-emergency events. The project will improve knowledge about human responses to emergency events by studying their behavioral signatures through key social science theories on fear or violence and crime, the social psychology of fear, threat, and risk, and the sociology of disasters.

Geospatial graphical models will be at the core of the machine learning tools for emergency-event identification. These novel models generalize Gaussian graphical models to non-Gaussian multiway tensor data with spatial and temporal dependencies across multiple dimensions, and represent contributions to statistical and machine learning theory. Multiway tensor geospatial graphical models have the ability to capture the uncertainty in unknown multivariate interactions together with known dependencies (e.g., spatial) in a coherent manner. Non-separable spatiotemporal versions of these models will be developed as extensions of Bayesian dynamic linear models, and of multivariate factor models with correlated residuals. By exploiting the theory on Markov marked point processes and multivariate birth-death processes, this project will develop efficient, robust methods of inference and model determination. The methodological research on geospatial graphical models has a vast domain of applicability that encompasses all the scientific fields in which the analysis of multivariate spatiotemporal datasets is key: public health policy, social and political sciences, finance, electrical engineering, and computer science. These models are directly applicable in the analysis of high-resolution smartphone-based GPS locations datasets, which are now actively being collected in studies that seek to characterize the relationship between geographic and contextual attributes of the environment and human energy balance, to study segregation, environmental exposure, and accessibility in social science research, or to understand the relationship between health-risk behavior in adolescents and community disorder. The patterns and cross-national variance in response to emergency events will also inform the social sciences.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerns the development of novel statistical models for representing human mobility based on geolocated data. Special consideration was given to the identification of changes in human mobility patterns after the occurrence of major emergency events such as earthquakes, hurricanes, drought, wild fire or civil unrest. The research team curated and organized databases of geolocated emergency events and geolocated Twitter data. 

 

Intellectual merit

Human responses to hazardous events have long been a mainstay of social science and policy interest. Our research found that historical contextualization of extreme, dangerous events has substantial relevance for event identification systems and effective messaging for warning and possible evacuation prior to the occurrence of such events. Another key finding relates to major improvements in the accuracy in the identification of the type and spatiotemporal scale of an extreme event based on sequences of extreme events that occurred in the past. These two findings – historical context and putting hazardous events in sequence – represent a major departure from the current literature that focuses on the identification of single extreme events that are spatially and temporally isolated from other – possibly related – extreme events. The need to account for historical context and sequences of events is especially relevant when signatures of hazardous events are captured from human mobility data.

 

Our team developed new methods for determination of graphical loglinear models using birth-death MCMC and introduced clique loglinear models. Such models are needed for the analysis of high-dimensional, hyper-sparse contingency tables. Our team employed these models to study migration patterns in a rural area of South Africa for people who are at high risk of HIV infection. We made theoretical contributions related to the Bayesian inference and model selection for single factor models with correlated residuals. We put forward a novel method for assessing the temporal stability of spatiotemporal trajectories of human mobility based on GPS data. We proposed a novel nonparametric method called density ranking for quantifying individuals’ dynamic exposure to social and environmental risk factors based on measuring activity spaces from geolocated data. We also introduced a novel mixture model for representing human activity spaces and studied its asymptotic properties. We studied methods for identification of mediating variables based on graphical models.

 

Broader Impacts

Our research has immediate relevance in social and biomedical studies that involve human mobility. The methods we developed provide a principled approach to estimating the frequency, extent, duration and temporal stability of spatiotemporal trajectories followed by individuals during their everyday life. Our activities led to the publication of seven research articles. We finalized two additional manuscripts that have been submitted for publication. This project provided support for one PhD student in Sociology, one Master student in Sociology and two PhD students in Statistics. Seven other graduate students in data science have also participated to our research activities. The research contributed to the development of one R package.
